items.title: Far future expire header and HTTP 304
items.content_html:
I’m trying to optimize the loading time of a website. One of the things I’ve done is set a far-futures expires header for static content so that they are cached (as described by Yahoo). However, even though they are cached, the browser still sends a request and gets back a 304 (Not Modified) response for that resource.

I realize the 304 response is very small and probably has minimal performance effect, but is there a way to make it such that the browser will no longer send the request at all and just always use the cache for that resource?
items.summary:
I’m trying to optimize the loading time of a website. One of the things I’ve done is set a far-futures expires header for static content so that they are cached (as described by Yahoo). However, even though they are cached, the browser still sends a request and gets back a 304 (Not Modified) response for that resource.
I realize the 304 response is very small and probably has minimal performance effect, but is there a way to make it such that the browser will no longer send the request at all and just always use the cache for that resource?

items.content_html: You can assign it a value that is specific to the object instance, which you can’t do with a static class variable.

items.content_html: It’s been a while, but I think browser security settings normally will not allow you to set the contents of <input type="file” /> programmatically, resulting in some security exception when you submit.
items.summary: It’s been a while, but I think browser security settings normally will not allow you to set the contents of <input type="file” /> programmatically, resulting in some security exception when you submit.

items.title: screen sharing library
items.content_html:
I’m looking into screen sharing functionality - i.e. allowing remote users to view your desktop in real time, possibly control it and write annotations (text/drawings) on the shared screen. Something similar to what webex allows in its conferencing software. Preferably a Java-based api, possibly to run from an applet.

Any recommendations on a library/api to use?
items.summary:
I’m looking into screen sharing functionality - i.e. allowing remote users to view your desktop in real time, possibly control it and write annotations (text/drawings) on the shared screen. Something similar to what webex allows in its conferencing software. Preferably a Java-based api, possibly to run from an applet.
Any recommendations on a library/api to use?

items.content_html:
urlpatterns = patterns('',     
    (r'^salaries/employee/$', list_detail.object_list, 'employee_info'),
)

The third item in the tuple needs to be a dictionary, not a string. Try removing the single quotes around employee_info:

urlpatterns = patterns('',     
    (r'^salaries/employee/$', list_detail.object_list, employee_info),
)
items.summary:
urlpatterns = patterns('', (r'^salaries/employee/$', list_detail.object_list, 'employee_info'), )  The third item in the tuple needs to be a dictionary, not a string. Try removing the single quotes around employee_info:
urlpatterns = patterns('', (r'^salaries/employee/$', list_detail.object_list, employee_info), )

items.content_html: In addition to the answers above, on Oracle RDBMS, “delete” is a transaction that can be rolled back if you didn’t commit. “Truncate” cannot.

items.title: Alternatives to Bouncy Castle java library for PKCS7 encryption/signing?
items.content_html: We’ve always used the BouncyCastle library, I’m being asked if there are other viable alternatives, either open source or not. Or is the BouncyCastle library already the best one to use?
